mirt 1.32.9
  • Reference

  • Changelog

Convert ordered Likert-scale responses (character or factors) to integers

Source: R/likert2int.R
likert2int.Rd

Given a matrix or data.frame object consisting of Likert responses return an object of the same dimensions with integer values.

likert2int(x, levels = NULL)

Arguments

x

a matrix of character values or data.frame of character/factor vectors
levels

a named character vector indicating which integer values should be assigned to which elements. If omitted, the order of the elements will be determined after converting each column in x to a factor variable

References

Chalmers, R., P. (2012). mirt: A Multidimensional Item Response Theory Package for the R Environment. Journal of Statistical Software, 48(6), 1-29. doi: 10.18637/jss.v048.i06

See also

key2binary, poly2dich

Author

Phil Chalmers rphilip.chalmers@gmail.com

Examples

# \donttest{

#simulate data

dat1 <- matrix(sample(c('Disagree', 'Strongly Disagree', 'Agree',
                        'Neutral', 'Strongly Agree'), 1000*5, replace=TRUE),
               nrow=1000, ncol=5)
dat1[2,2] <- dat1[3,3] <- dat1[1,3] <- NA # NAs added for flavour
dat2 <- matrix(sample(c('D', 'SD', 'A', 'N', 'SA'), 1000*5, replace=TRUE),
               nrow=1000, ncol=5)
dat <- cbind(dat1, dat2)

# separately
intdat1 <- likert2int(dat1)
head(dat1)

#>      [,1]             [,2]                [,3]       [,4]            
#> [1,] "Neutral"        "Strongly Agree"    NA         "Neutral"       
#> [2,] "Agree"          NA                  "Agree"    "Strongly Agree"
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Disagree" NA         "Disagree"      
#> [4,] "Neutral"        "Neutral"           "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [5,] "Disagree"       "Disagree"          "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [6,] "Neutral"        "Disagree"          "Neutral"  "Disagree"      
#>      [,5]               
#> [1,] "Agree"            
#> [2,] "Strongly Agree"   
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree"   
#> [4,] "Strongly Disagree"
#> [5,] "Strongly Disagree"
#> [6,] "Strongly Disagree"
head(intdat1)

#>   V1 V2 V3 V4 V5
#> 1 NA NA NA NA NA
#> 2 NA NA NA NA NA
#> 3 NA NA NA NA NA
#> 4 NA NA NA NA NA
#> 5 NA NA NA NA NA
#> 6 NA NA NA NA NA

# more useful with explicit levels
lvl1 <- c('Strongly Disagree'=1, 'Disagree'=2, 'Neutral'=3, 'Agree'=4,
          'Strongly Agree'=5)
intdat1 <- likert2int(dat1, levels = lvl1)
head(dat1)

#>      [,1]             [,2]                [,3]       [,4]            
#> [1,] "Neutral"        "Strongly Agree"    NA         "Neutral"       
#> [2,] "Agree"          NA                  "Agree"    "Strongly Agree"
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Disagree" NA         "Disagree"      
#> [4,] "Neutral"        "Neutral"           "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [5,] "Disagree"       "Disagree"          "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [6,] "Neutral"        "Disagree"          "Neutral"  "Disagree"      
#>      [,5]               
#> [1,] "Agree"            
#> [2,] "Strongly Agree"   
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree"   
#> [4,] "Strongly Disagree"
#> [5,] "Strongly Disagree"
#> [6,] "Strongly Disagree"
head(intdat1)

#>   V1 V2 V3 V4 V5
#> 1  3  5 NA  3  4
#> 2  4 NA  4  5  5
#> 3  5  1 NA  2  5
#> 4  3  3  2  5  1
#> 5  2  2  2  5  1
#> 6  3  2  3  2  1

# second data
lvl2 <- c('SD'=1, 'D'=2, 'N'=3, 'A'=4, 'SA'=5)
intdat2 <- likert2int(dat2, levels = lvl2)
head(dat2)

#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5]
#> [1,] "D"  "D"  "A"  "D"  "N" 
#> [2,] "SD" "D"  "SA" "D"  "D" 
#> [3,] "N"  "N"  "D"  "A"  "D" 
#> [4,] "SD" "D"  "D"  "SA" "SD"
#> [5,] "N"  "SA" "N"  "A"  "SD"
#> [6,] "SA" "SD" "SD" "A"  "SA"
head(intdat2)

#>   V1 V2 V3 V4 V5
#> 1  2  2  4  2  3
#> 2  1  2  5  2  2
#> 3  3  3  2  4  2
#> 4  1  2  2  5  1
#> 5  3  5  3  4  1
#> 6  5  1  1  4  5

# full dataset (using both mapping schemes)
intdat <- likert2int(dat, levels = c(lvl1, lvl2))
head(dat)

#>      [,1]             [,2]                [,3]       [,4]            
#> [1,] "Neutral"        "Strongly Agree"    NA         "Neutral"       
#> [2,] "Agree"          NA                  "Agree"    "Strongly Agree"
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Disagree" NA         "Disagree"      
#> [4,] "Neutral"        "Neutral"           "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [5,] "Disagree"       "Disagree"          "Disagree" "Strongly Agree"
#> [6,] "Neutral"        "Disagree"          "Neutral"  "Disagree"      
#>      [,5]                [,6] [,7] [,8] [,9] [,10]
#> [1,] "Agree"             "D"  "D"  "A"  "D"  "N"  
#> [2,] "Strongly Agree"    "SD" "D"  "SA" "D"  "D"  
#> [3,] "Strongly Agree"    "N"  "N"  "D"  "A"  "D"  
#> [4,] "Strongly Disagree" "SD" "D"  "D"  "SA" "SD" 
#> [5,] "Strongly Disagree" "N"  "SA" "N"  "A"  "SD" 
#> [6,] "Strongly Disagree" "SA" "SD" "SD" "A"  "SA" 
head(intdat)

#>   V1 V2 V3 V4 V5 V6 V7 V8 V9 V10
#> 1  3  5 NA  3  4  2  2  4  2   3
#> 2  4 NA  4  5  5  1  2  5  2   2
#> 3  5  1 NA  2  5  3  3  2  4   2
#> 4  3  3  2  5  1  1  2  2  5   1
#> 5  2  2  2  5  1  3  5  3  4   1
#> 6  3  2  3  2  1  5  1  1  4   5


#####
# data.frame as input with ordered factors

dat1 <- data.frame(dat1)
dat2 <- data.frame(dat2)
dat.old <- cbind(dat1, dat2)
colnames(dat.old) <- paste0('Item_', 1:10)
str(dat.old) # factors are leveled alphabetically by default

#> 'data.frame':	1000 obs. of  10 variables:
#>  $ Item_1 : chr  "Neutral" "Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Neutral" ...
#>  $ Item_2 : chr  "Strongly Agree" NA "Strongly Disagree" "Neutral" ...
#>  $ Item_3 : chr  NA "Agree" NA "Disagree" ...
#>  $ Item_4 : chr  "Neutral" "Strongly Agree" "Disagree" "Strongly Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_5 : chr  "Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Disagree" ...
#>  $ Item_6 : chr  "D" "SD" "N" "SD" ...
#>  $ Item_7 : chr  "D" "D" "N" "D" ...
#>  $ Item_8 : chr  "A" "SA" "D" "D" ...
#>  $ Item_9 : chr  "D" "D" "A" "SA" ...
#>  $ Item_10: chr  "N" "D" "D" "SD" ...

# create explicit ordering in factor variables
for(i in 1:ncol(dat1))
   levels(dat1[[i]]) <- c('Strongly Disagree', 'Disagree', 'Neutral', 'Agree',
                          'Strongly Agree')

for(i in 1:ncol(dat2))
   levels(dat2[[i]]) <- c('SD', 'D', 'N', 'A', 'SA')

dat <- cbind(dat1, dat2)
colnames(dat) <- colnames(dat.old)
str(dat) # note ordering

#> 'data.frame':	1000 obs. of  10 variables:
#>  $ Item_1 : chr  "Neutral" "Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Neutral" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "Strongly Disagree" "Disagree" "Neutral" "Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_2 : chr  "Strongly Agree" NA "Strongly Disagree" "Neutral" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "Strongly Disagree" "Disagree" "Neutral" "Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_3 : chr  NA "Agree" NA "Disagree" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "Strongly Disagree" "Disagree" "Neutral" "Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_4 : chr  "Neutral" "Strongly Agree" "Disagree" "Strongly Agree" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "Strongly Disagree" "Disagree" "Neutral" "Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_5 : chr  "Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Agree" "Strongly Disagree" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "Strongly Disagree" "Disagree" "Neutral" "Agree" ...
#>  $ Item_6 : chr  "D" "SD" "N" "SD" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "SD" "D" "N" "A" ...
#>  $ Item_7 : chr  "D" "D" "N" "D" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "SD" "D" "N" "A" ...
#>  $ Item_8 : chr  "A" "SA" "D" "D" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "SD" "D" "N" "A" ...
#>  $ Item_9 : chr  "D" "D" "A" "SA" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "SD" "D" "N" "A" ...
#>  $ Item_10: chr  "N" "D" "D" "SD" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "levels")= chr [1:5] "SD" "D" "N" "A" ...

intdat <- likert2int(dat)
head(dat)

#>           Item_1            Item_2   Item_3         Item_4            Item_5
#> 1        Neutral    Strongly Agree     <NA>        Neutral             Agree
#> 2          Agree              <NA>    Agree Strongly Agree    Strongly Agree
#> 3 Strongly Agree Strongly Disagree     <NA>       Disagree    Strongly Agree
#> 4        Neutral           Neutral Disagree Strongly Agree Strongly Disagree
#> 5       Disagree          Disagree Disagree Strongly Agree Strongly Disagree
#> 6        Neutral          Disagree  Neutral       Disagree Strongly Disagree
#>   Item_6 Item_7 Item_8 Item_9 Item_10
#> 1      D      D      A      D       N
#> 2     SD      D     SA      D       D
#> 3      N      N      D      A       D
#> 4     SD      D      D     SA      SD
#> 5      N     SA      N      A      SD
#> 6     SA     SD     SD      A      SA
head(intdat)

#>   Item_1 Item_2 Item_3 Item_4 Item_5 Item_6 Item_7 Item_8 Item_9 Item_10
#> 1      3      5     NA      3      4      2      2      4      2       3
#> 2      4     NA      4      5      5      1      2      5      2       2
#> 3      5      1     NA      2      5      3      3      2      4       2
#> 4      3      3      2      5      1      1      2      2      5       1
#> 5      2      2      2      5      1      3      5      3      4       1
#> 6      3      2      3      2      1      5      1      1      4       5

# }
